title: Pay study information request

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: Pay study information request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

The results of the 2023 St. Louis County Pay Study conducted by CBIZ, all emails between St. Louis County Government and CBIZ, all internal communications between St. Louis County employees regarding the pay study, all communications to and from County Executive Sam Page regarding the study and any internal communications regarding the withholding or release of the results.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brandon Derickson

title: Request to Air Force for list of 2022 film collaborations

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Request to Air Force for list of 2022 film collaborations
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A list of all the films that the U.S. Air Force has participated in the production of, in any capacity whatsoever, for the year 2022. I request that you search for these documents in any location where they might be located, including but not limited to the entertainment liaison offices and communications HQ. 

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called the Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

title: Communications between CMS and FDA regarding Aduhelm

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Communications between CMS and FDA regarding Aduhelm
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

-All communications between CMS and FDA regarding Aduhelm (Aducanumab) and/or monoclonal antibodies directed against amyloid for the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease between the dates of January 1, 2017 and September 1, 2023. 

I am a fellow at Columbia University's Toni Stabile Center for Investigative Journalism. This is an educational request.

I submitting this FOIA request to understand the rationale and reasoning of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (“CMS”) in issuing its April 7, 2022 National Coverage Determination regarding Monoclonal Antibodies Directed Against Amyloid for the Treatment of Alzheimer’s Disease, CAG-00460N (“NCD”).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Juan Vassallo

communications.communication:

  * Or Deny the request in writing, stating the reasons for the denial (this could also include a denial of part of your request and a granting of the remainder).

title: Twitter Files Publicly Disclosed

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Twitter Files Publicly Disclosed
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear Sirs:
This letter constitutes a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, on behalf of Targeted Justice Inc.
I request that a copy of the following documents [or documents containing the following information] be provided to Targeted Justice:
1.	A list including account name, owner and twitter handle of all the Twitter accounts publicly revealed to journalists Matt Taibbi, Bari Weiss and Michael Shellenberger that were monitored, manipulated and-or altered by FBI operatives. 
2.	A copy of all the [Spectra Baker emails delivered to journalists Matt Taibbi and-or Bari Weiss.
3.	FBI emails, Standard Operating Procedures, Memorandum of Understanding, letters, emails or any other document establishing the parameters for instructions to social media platforms on content moderation decisions.
The term “document” is to be liberally construed to include any file, paper, microfilm, digital archive, or any other format where the information sought may be stored.
As you know, FOIA requires agencies to release information unless it is specifically exempt from disclosure, and also requires agencies to release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of documents, i.e., to redact exempt portions of documents and release the rest. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(8).
Targeted Justice's status as a news organization that provides information of public interest to its members warrants the expedited processing of this Request on the grounds that there is a compelling need for these records because the information requested is urgently needed by an organization primarily engaged in disseminating information in order to inform the public about actual or alleged Federal Government activity. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II); see also 22 C.F.R. § 171.12(b)(2); 28 C.F.R. § n16.5(d)(1)(ii); 32 C.F.R. § 286.4(d)(3)(ii); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.34(c)(2).
Request for expedited processing
Targeted Justice currently has over 9,000 subscribers and over 115,000 thousands views a month in its Substack newsletter. Thus, pursuant to 47 CFR 0.466 it is a news media organization.
Targeted Justice also requests the expedited processing of this request on the grounds that the records and documents requested relate to a “breaking news story of general public interest”. Furthermore, they present a “matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government’s integrity which affect public confidence”. Expedited processing is warranted when “the information is relevant to a subject of public urgency concerning an actual or alleged Federal government activity” See 22 C.F.R. § 171.12(b)(2)(i); 32 C.F.R. § 286.4(d)(3)(ii)(A); see also 28 C.F.R. § 16.5(d)(1)(iv); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.34(c)(2).

In light of the above, Targeted Justice requests that your agency adheres to the legal mandate contained in 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i); see 28 C.F.R. § 16.6(b), (c) and consequently produce within 20 days of receipt of this request the information sought.
Request for Fee Waiver
Targeted Justice hereby requests a fee waiver of search, review, and duplication fees on the grounds that disclosure of the requested records is “in the public interest because it is likely to significantly contribute to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester.” See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii); see also 22 C.F.R. § 171.17(a); 28 C.F.R. § 16.11(k); 32 C.F.R. § 286.28(d); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.13(b)(2).
Furthermore, a waiver of search and review fees is warranted inasmuch as Targeted Justice will report the results of this endeavor on the grounds that Targeted Justice qualifies as a “representative of the news media” and that the records are not sought for commercial use. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii))(7); 32 C.F.R. §§ 1900.02(h)(3), 1900.13(i)(2).
For any document you fail to produce, Targeted Justice requests that you provide a Vaughn Index and declaration setting forth reasonably detailed explanations for each withheld document as to why it falls within any statutory exemption. See Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973). The Vaughn statement must specify details about each document's sender, recipients, date and time, and subject.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Targeted Justice

title: Automated License Plate Reader Licensing

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Automated License Plate Reader Licensing
communications.communication:
Dear Custodian of Records:

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 

- All purchase orders, invoices and statements of work associated with automated license plate readers or ALPR data (including the companies Flock Safety, Vigilant Solutions, Motorola Solutions, Axon and Lehr Auto) for the period Jan 1, 2022 through today's date;
- All operative contracts and agreements with the above stated companies regarding ALPR systems or ALPR data for the period Jan 1, 2022 through today's date. 


CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 
Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

communications.subject: Fwd: Freedom of Information Act Request: Scott Gordon Perry service records
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Serna:

Thank you for submitting your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to
the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) via email to
foia@nara.gov. We received your request on September 28, 2023.  Your
request states:

*All military service records for Scott Gordon Perry, DOB: May 27, 1962,
including but not limited to discharge paperwork, training logs, and
service awards.*

Due to the nature of your inquiry, we are forwarding your request by this
email to the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC) for Military Records
in St. Louis for appropriate handling.  The NPRC will assign your request a
tracking number and respond directly to you.  In the future, if you need to
contact the NPRC, you can do so by mail or fax to the following address:

National Personnel Records Center
1 Archives Drive
St. Louis, Missouri 63138

Telephone:   314-801-0800
Telephone (Toll Free):  1-866-272-6272 (only within the US)
Fax:  314-801-9195

For your reference, below you will find your original submission.

On our website at https://www.archives.gov/veterans/military-service-records
you can find information about requesting Official Military Personnel Files
(OMPFs) that are not yet archival records fully open to the public.  At the
website for the National Archives at St. Louis,
https://www.archives.gov/st-louis/ <https://www.archives.gov/st-louis/%20>,
you will find information about requesting Official Military Personnel
Files that are now archival records open to the public.  The OMPF normally
becomes an archival record 62 years after the date of discharge.

At www.archives.gov/foia <http://www.archives.gov/foia%20> we provide
information about FOIA.  On our home page, www.archives.gov, you can learn
about the resources that we offer to the public, and access our online
catalog.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and pursuant to guidance received from the
Office of Management and Budget (OMB), NARA had adjusted its normal
operations to balance the need of completing its mission-critical work
while also adhering to the recommended social distancing for the safety of
our staff.  NPRC is working with a reduced on site staff who are
prioritizing veterans' burial requests, homeless veterans, and medical
emergency requests.  As a result of this re-prioritization of activities,
you may experience a delay in receiving a substantive response to your FOIA
request.  We apologize for this inconvenience and appreciate your
understanding and patience.

Sincerely,

title: Locomotive Engineer Training Materials

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Locomotive Engineer Training Materials
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

- Complete course descriptions and syllabi for elements of the locomotive engineer training program 
- All training materials given to locomotive engineer trainees including, but not limited to, digital text files such as PDF and Microsoft Word documents, copies of any materials physically given to trainees without a digital equivalent, and any computer applications utilized by locomotive engineer trainees to receive instruction remotely.
- Lecture materials including, but not limited to,  powerpoint presentations, assignments, instructor-provided lecture notes, videos of lectures both pre-recorded and live recorded if distributed to trainees, written tests/assessments taken by the trainees without enclosing the answer key for aforementioned tests, 
- Any instructional guides given to locomotive engineer training participants, as well as used by locomotive engineer training instructors, both created by Amtrak as well as those created by a third-party vendor and supplied to Amtrak and used for training locomotive engineers .
- Amtrak's operating rules, operating manuals and procedures for the ACS-64, P32AC-DM, and Acela Express trainsets, and any other resource that Amtrak would provide to a locomotive engineer trainee.
- For the above requests, if a type of material given to a trainee differs based on base location and route assignment, select  only the material given to a trainee who would be qualifying for locomotive operation on the Northeast Corridor either operating a Northeast Regional service or on an Acela Express service if possible.
- Any materials not mentioned above given to locomotive engineer trainees over the course of their training program to become qualified both to operate Amtrak equipment in general, as well as on the Northeast Corridor operating the Northeast Regional and Acela Express services in particular.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Avi Koenig

title: ICE DCRA Forms 2015-2023

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: ICE DCRA Forms 2015-2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Death In Custody Reporting Act report forms submitted by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) to DOJ-BJP. Please see the linked final response from ICE to our prior request for these forms from ICE. https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/23994964-foia-appeal-adjudication-letter-2023-icap-00450-2023-icfo-26205-affirm-search

We note that ICE initially denied our FOIA request on the ground that it has no records because DCRA does not apply to the agency. On appeal, IC admits the applicability of DCRA, but claims the agency fills out the form online and doesn’t keep a copy. Accordingly, we are requesting copies from DOJ BJP. 

Thank you for your prompt and complete response to this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

communications.subject: Fwd: Freedom of Information Act Request: Mark Keith Robinson service records
communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Serna:

Thank you for submitting your Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request to
the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) via email to
foia@nara.gov. We received your request on September 28, 2023.  Your
request states:

*Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following
records: All military service records for Mark Keith Robinson, DOB: August
18, 1968, including but not limited to discharge paperwork, training logs,
and service awards.*

Due to the nature of your inquiry, we are forwarding your request by this
email to the National Personnel Records Center (NPRC) for Military Records
in St. Louis for appropriate handling.  The NPRC will assign your request a
tracking number and respond directly to you.  In the future, if you need to
contact the NPRC, you can do so by mail or fax to the following address:

National Personnel Records Center
1 Archives Drive
St. Louis, Missouri 63138

Telephone:   314-801-0800
Telephone (Toll Free):  1-866-272-6272 (only within the US)
Fax:  314-801-9195

For your reference, below you will find your original submission.

On our website at https://www.archives.gov/veterans/military-service-records
you can find information about requesting Official Military Personnel Files
(OMPFs) that are not yet archival records fully open to the public.  At the
website for the National Archives at St. Louis,
https://www.archives.gov/st-louis/ <https://www.archives.gov/st-louis/%20>,
you will find information about requesting Official Military Personnel
Files that are now archival records open to the public.  The OMPF normally
becomes an archival record 62 years after the date of discharge.

At www.archives.gov/foia <http://www.archives.gov/foia%20> we provide
information about FOIA.  On our home page, www.archives.gov, you can learn
about the resources that we offer to the public, and access our online
catalog.

Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and pursuant to guidance received from the
Office of Management and Budget (OMB), NARA had adjusted its normal
operations to balance the need of completing its mission-critical work
while also adhering to the recommended social distancing for the safety of
our staff.  NPRC is working with a reduced on site staff who are
prioritizing veterans' burial requests, homeless veterans, and medical
emergency requests.  As a result of this re-prioritization of activities,
you may experience a delay in receiving a substantive response to your FOIA
request.  We apologize for this inconvenience and appreciate your
understanding and patience.

Sincerely,
Ashley Bryan
Government Information Specialist
Office of General Counsel (NGC)
National Archives and Records Administration
8601 Adelphi Road
College Park, Maryland, 20740-6001
301-837-3642

communications.subject: Re: Freedom of Information Act Request: Mark Keith Robinson service records
communications.communication:
Mr. Serna,

The National Archives holds Federal military service records from the
Revolutionary War to 1912 in the National Archives in Washington, D.C.
Military service records from WWI - present are held in the National
Military Personnel Records Center (NPRC), in St. Louis, Missouri. See
details of holdings.

Sincerely,

Ashley Bryan
Government Information Specialist

National Archives and Records Administration
8601 Adelphi Road
College Park, Maryland, 20740-6001

communications.subject: How to Submit for Military Records
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting the National Personnel Records Center. If you 
would like to submit a request, you may do so online at 
http://vetrecs.archives.gov, and select the blue “Start Request Online” 
button. We cannot provide an estimated completion date at this time. 

Alternatively, you can complete a Standard form 180 using the link below. 
https://www.archives.gov/files/research/order/standard-form-180.pdf  

FAX to (314) 801-9195 or mail it to our Center at:

National Personnel Records Center

Military Personnel Records

1 Archives Drive

Saint Louis, MO 63138 
Please do not reply to this email. Please call (314) 801-0800 if you have 
any questions.

Thank you,
KC

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: MO Courts Civil Rights Cases/Conspiracy Against Rights/Deprivation of Rights Under Color of Law
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

Court documents or court records related to complaint filings or lawsuit filings, prosecutions or convictions for cases filed for civil rights violations related to Conspiracy Against Rights and/or Deprivation of Rights Under Color of Law filed against the actions of any employees, agents or representatives acting under the authority of any local, state or federal law enforcement agencies operating in the state of Missouri.  Please provide court documents or court records filed in any of the Missouri Judicial Circuit Courts or Appellate District Courts between the dates of July 1, 2012 and the date of your acknowledgement of receipt of this request.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not for commercial usage.

In the event that fees cannot be waived, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available. 

If any portion of materials responsive to this request should be deemed unavailable or exempt from disclosure, please specifically identify the portions of the records or the specific information that is unavailable and the reason for the exemption.

If any portion of this request is too broad, unclear or can be modified to reduce the burden placed on your agency’s ability to produce responsive documents or provide documents more efficiently or expeditiously, please reply with a request for clarification or suggested modifications or revisions.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kevin Hawkins

title: Signalling System 7 (SS7) on mobile phone networks

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Signalling System 7 (SS7) on mobile phone networks
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records pertaining to FCC investigation, technical assessment and regulation of mobile phone companies' use of the Signaling System 7 (SS7) network infrastructure for the exchange of customer account, call and message information between companies. This issue was studied by a working group in 2017 (CSRIC Working Group 10). I am interested in a) any documents used to develop the final report of this working group in March 2017; and b) any documents pertaining to work done since the issuance of the working group's final report and the public notice by FCC Public Safety and Homeland Security Bureau.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Ray Robinson

title: Cell Towers with microwave beamforming antenna arrays

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:
This is a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, et seq. 
Targeted Justice is a news and human rights organization. 
On behalf of Targeted Justice, I request that you provide a copy of the following documents [or documents containing the following information:
1) List of licensed and non-licensed cellular antenna arrays equipped with Microwave Beamforming Integrated Circuits (IC),  used to configure a beamforming antenna array, manufactured under US patent number  10,164,694, including name of owner, operator, date installed or built, permit number and address.
2) Copies of all cellular tower employee complaints entailing microwave burns at FCC-regulated facilities for the past 5 years and subsequent agency action/determination.
3) List of licensed and non-licensed cellular antenna arrays equipped with frequency multiplier equipment capable of generating with an output of 60-65 GHz, including name of owner, operator, date installed or built, permit number and address.
4) Copies of all agency determinations for the past 5 years revoking a cellular tower antenna permit for violating any terms of its terms and conditions.
The term “document” is to be liberally construed to include any file, paper, microfilm, digital archive, or any other format where the information sought may be stored.
As you know, FOIA requires agencies to release information unless it is specifically exempt from disclosure, and also requires agencies to release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of documents, i.e., to redact exempt portions of documents and release the rest. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(8). Pursuant to the CIA’s Historical Review Program regulations:
“In no case will information be kept classified in order to conceal violations of law, inefficiency, or administrative error; to prevent embarrassment to a person, organization, or agency; or to prevent or delay the release of information that does not require protection in the interest of national security.”
Targeted Justice's status as a news organization that provides information of public interest to its members warrants the expedited processing of this request because there is a compelling need for these records. Our organization urgently needs the information requested because we are primarily engaged in disseminating information in order to inform the public about actual or alleged Federal Government activity. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II); see also 22 C.F.R. § 171.12(b)(2); 28 C.F.R. § n16.5(d)(1)(ii); 32 C.F.R. § 286.4(d)(3)(ii); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.34(c)(2).
Request for expedited processing
Targeted Justice requests the expedited processing of this request because the records and documents requested relate to a “breaking news story of general public interest”. Furthermore, they present a “matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government’s integrity which affect public confidence”. Expedited processing is warranted when “the information is relevant to a subject of public urgency concerning an actual or alleged Federal government activity” See 22 C.F.R. § 171.12(b)(2)(i); 32 C.F.R. § 286.4(d)(3)(ii)(A); see also 28 C.F.R. § 16.5(d)(1)(iv); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.34(c)(2).
In light of the above, Targeted Justice requests that your agency adheres to the legal mandate contained in 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i); see 28 C.F.R. § 16.6(b), (c) and consequently produce within 20 days of receipt of this request the information sought.
Request for Fee Waiver
Targeted Justice hereby requests a fee waiver of search, review, and duplication fees on the grounds that disclosure of the requested records is “in the public interest because it is likely to significantly contribute to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester.” See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii); see also 22 C.F.R. § 171.17(a); 28 C.F.R. § 16.11(k); 32 C.F.R. § 286.28(d); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.13(b)(2).
You can produce all the documents requested in an indexed, digital format.
Furthermore, a waiver of search and review fees is warranted inasmuch as Targeted Justice will report the results of this endeavor on the grounds that Targeted Justice qualifies as a “representative of the news media” and that the records are not sought for commercial use. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii))(7); 32 C.F.R. §§ 1900.02(h)(3), 1900.13(i)(2).
For any document you fail to produce, Targeted Justice requests that you provide a Vaughn Index and declaration setting forth reasonably detailed explanations for each withheld document as to why it falls within any statutory exemption. See Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973). Provided that the Vaughn statement must specify details about each document's sender, recipients, date and time, and subject.
If you need to discuss this request, you can reach our attorney Ana L. Toledo at 832-247-3046. Thank you for your consideration of my request.
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.
Sincerely,
Winter Calvert for 
Targeted Justice, Inc.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Winter Calvert

communications.subject: Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request: Central Michigan University
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Thank you for your attention to our request. I am writing to request payroll records (for all employees of your institution) from 1984 to 2022 in excel format (same format as the records provided in Adam Goldstein's request filed 9/20 for 2019-2020 records). The information I am looking for is nonpersonal (ie: Name, title, annual pay, year associated with pay, job description). We would like disaggregated figures, not aggregated. To assist in this process, I have listed with more specificity, the information we are looking for: 

Annual Payroll Records of all, including full time, part time, and student, employees on your institution’s payroll with fields:
Name (first and last)
Total Annual Pay (can be summed or disaggregated into base pay, other pay, overtime pay, benefits, etc).
Title
Year
Department
Job description: the roles, responsibilities and duties of an employee’s title. 
If the institution has a system of categorizing employees please include their categorization and corresponding codebook if relevant. 

To the extent any of these records may not exist or may not be disclosed, please disclose any segregable parts of relevant documents.

Please note that this request does not seek a search of faculty or student email accounts or records. These requests should in no way be construed to include a review or search of email accounts, websites, or other forms of data or document retention which are controlled by students, alumni, or faculty members, nor by governmental or advisory bodies controlled by the same, except insofar as any such individuals also serve in an administrative capacity and the records were created or are held by the individual in that capacity. Any search should be limited to documents held by the administration and/or its staff members, including records created or maintained by persons acting in the capacity of administrators or staff members.

This request is made on behalf of the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, a nonprofit and nonpartisan organization that aims to defend and sustain the individual rights of all Americans to free speech and free thought. This request concerns a matter of public interest. The records are sought for the purpose of quantifying staffing and spending changes over time. They are ultimately part of a project to research and educate the public about the makeup of staffing in higher education.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Goldstein

title: Discussions regarding N95 use between Dec 2019 and June 2020

communications.communication:

I am seeking records discussing the issuance of rules, regulations, and guidance, around workplace use of N95s and/or higher grade respirators, to prevent transmission of COVID in the workplace between December 1, 2019, and June 1, 2020.

I am also seeking records discussing the issuance of rules, regulations, and guidance, around workplace use of PPE of a lesser grade than N95 respirators - namely, but not limited to, surgical masks, cloth masks, face shields, and similar facial PPE used in place of the aforementioned - between December 1, 2019, and June 1, 2020.

Should this be too broad a search, but only if that is too broad a search, you may narrow it only discussions that involve alignment with the CDC guidelines - I am not seeking the actual interagency communications.

title: Nuisance Ordinance Information Request

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Nuisance Ordinance Information Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oregon Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all records from the past two years (September 2021-September 2023) regarding your nuisance property ordinance that will be referred to as "ordinance"  in this request but could be known (but not limited to) as "Chronic Nuisance Property" as described in Portland's city code Chapter 14B.60.

Please provide any and all written records (including but not limited to hard-copy documents, memos, emails, word processor documents, PDF documents, PowerPoint files, images files, video files etc.) regarding the Ordinance including but not limited to:

• any training/presentation materials used in communication, promotions, workshops, seminars, etc

• criminal background checks performed on prospective tenants

• evictions filed by property owners and number of tenants evicted as a result of the program and ordinance

• suspensions or revocation of a residential rental license, against property owners who fail to comply with the requirements of the ordinance.

• police calls, reports, citations, or arrests, collected by the municipality police department for the purpose of enforcing the ordinance.

• meeting minutes and correspondence between municipality officials, regarding the implementation and enforcement of the ordinance

• all documents concerning the passage of the nuisance ordinance and any amendments to it, including communications with City elected officials, city staff, and others, and any data relied upon or reviewed as a part of the passage or amendments to the nuisance ordinance since September 2021 to September 2023.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Jenny Wadhwa

title: Records on Current/Active Human Experimentation Program

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

This is a request under the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552, et seq. and the holding in Sims v. Central Intelligence Agency, 642 F.2d 562 (1980).

Targeted Justice is a news and human rights organization. 

On behalf of Targeted Justice, I request that you provide a copy of the following documents [or documents containing the following information]:

2.	List of the names of institutions and researchers who had conducted research under any current human experimentation Program.
3.	List of non-consenting human experimentation subjects in the  current human experimentation “Program”.
4.	Memorandum of Understanding between CIA and agencies and countries for collaboration in the “Program”.

The term “document” is to be liberally construed to include any file, paper, microfilm, digital archive, or any other format where the information sought may be stored.

As you know, FOIA requires agencies to release information unless it is specifically exempt from disclosure, and also requires agencies to release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of documents, i.e., to redact exempt portions of documents and release the rest. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(8). Pursuant to the CIA’s Historical Review Program regulations:

“In no case will information be kept classified in order to conceal violations of law, inefficiency, or administrative error; to prevent embarrassment to a person, organization, or agency; or to prevent or delay the release of information that does not require protection in the interest of national security.”

Targeted Justice's status as a news organization that provides information of public interest to its members warrants the expedited processing of this request because there is a compelling need for these records.  Our organization urgently needs the information requested because we are primarily engaged in disseminating information in order to inform the public about actual or alleged Federal Government activity. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II); see also 22 C.F.R. § 171.12(b)(2); 28 C.F.R. § n16.5(d)(1)(ii); 32 C.F.R. § 286.4(d)(3)(ii); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.34(c)(2).

Request for expedited processing

Targeted Justice requests the expedited processing of this request because the records and documents requested relate to a “breaking news story of general public interest”. Furthermore, they present a “matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which there exist possible questions about the government’s integrity which affect public confidence”. Expedited processing is warranted when “the information is relevant to a subject of public urgency concerning an actual or alleged Federal government activity” See 22 C.F.R. § 171.12(b)(2)(i); 32 C.F.R. § 286.4(d)(3)(ii)(A); see also 28 C.F.R. § 16.5(d)(1)(iv); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.34(c)(2).

In light of the above, Targeted Justice requests that your agency adheres to the legal mandate contained in 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i); see 28 C.F.R. § 16.6(b), (c) and consequently produce within 20 days of receipt of this request the information sought.

Request for Fee Waiver

Targeted Justice hereby requests a fee waiver of search, review, and duplication fees on the grounds that disclosure of the requested records is “in the public interest because it is likely to significantly contribute to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester.” See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii); see also 22 C.F.R. § 171.17(a); 28 C.F.R. § 16.11(k); 32 C.F.R. § 286.28(d); 32 C.F.R. § 1900.13(b)(2).

You can produce all the documents requested in an indexed, digital format.

Furthermore, a waiver of search and review fees is warranted inasmuch as Targeted Justice will report the results of this endeavor on the grounds that Targeted Justice qualifies as a “representative of the news media” and that the records are not sought for commercial use. See 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(ii))(7); 32 C.F.R. §§ 1900.02(h)(3), 1900.13(i)(2).

For any document you fail to produce, Targeted Justice requests that you provide a Vaughn Index and declaration setting forth reasonably detailed explanations for each withheld document as to why it falls within any statutory exemption. See Vaughn v. Rosen, 484 F.2d 820 (D.C. Cir. 1973). Provided that the Vaughn statement must specify details about each document's sender, recipients, date and time, and subject.

If you need to discuss this request, you can reach our attorney Ana L. Toledo at 832-247-3046. Thank you for your consideration of my request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Winter Calvert
